castItem.roleDesc: Agent for Silvia in her escape.

set.p: SCENE, Verona; Milan; the frontiers of Mantua.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Cease to persuade, my loving Proteus:
Home-keeping youth have ever homely wits.
Were't not affection chains thy tender days
To the sweet glances of thy honor'd love,
I rather would entreat thy company
To see the wonders of the world abroad,
Than, living dully sluggardized at home,
Wear out thy youth with shapeless idleness.
But since thou lovest, love still and thrive therein,
Even as I would when I to love begin.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Wilt thou be gone? Sweet Valentine, adieu!
Think on thy Proteus, when thou haply seest
Some rare note-worthy object in thy travel:
Wish me partaker in thy happiness
When thou dost meet good hap; and in thy danger,
If ever danger do environ thee,
Commend thy grievance to my holy prayers,
For I will be thy beadsman, Valentine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And on a love-book pray for my success?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Upon some book I love I'll pray for thee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That's on some shallow story of deep love:
How young Leander cross'd the Hellespont.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: That's a deep story of a deeper love:
For he was more than over shoes in love.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis true; for you are over boots in love,
And yet you never swum the Hellespont.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Over the boots? nay, give me not the boots.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No, I will not, for it boots thee not.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: To be in love, where scorn is bought with groans;
Coy looks with heart-sore sighs; one fading moment's mirth
With twenty watchful, weary, tedious nights:
If haply won, perhaps a hapless gain;
If lost, why then a grievous labor won;
However, but a folly bought with wit,
Or else a wit by folly vanquished.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: So, by your circumstance, you call me fool.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: So, by your circumstance, I fear you'll prove.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: 'Tis love you cavil at: I am not Love.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Love is your master, for he masters you:
And he that is so yoked by a fool,
Methinks, should not be chronicled for wise.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Yet writers say, as in the sweetest bud
The eating canker dwells, so eating love
Inhabits in the finest wits of all.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And writers say, as the most forward bud
Is eaten by the canker ere it blow,
Even so by love the young and tender wit
Is turn'd to folly, blasting in the bud,
Losing his verdure even in the prime
And all the fair effects of future hopes.
But wherefore waste I time to counsel thee,
That art a votary to fond desire?
Once more adieu! my father at the road
Expects my coming, there to see me shipp'd.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: And thither will I bring thee, Valentine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sweet Proteus, no; now let us take our leave.
To Milan let me hear from thee by letters
Of thy success in love, and what news else
Betideth here in absence of thy friend;
And I likewise will visit thee with mine.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: All happiness bechance to thee in Milan!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: As much to you at home! and so,farewell. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: He after honor hunts, I after love:
He leaves his friends to dignify them more;
I leave myself, my friends and all, for love.
Thou, Julia, thou hast metamorphosed me,
Made me neglect my studies, lose my time,
War with good counsel, set the world at nought;
Made wit with musing weak, heart sick with thought. Enter SPEED.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Sir Proteus, save you! Saw you my master?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: But now he parted hence, to embark for Milan.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Twenty to one then he is shipp'd already,
And I have play'd the sheep in losing him.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Indeed, a sheep doth very often stray,
An if the shepherd be a while away.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
You conclude that my master is a
shepherd, then,
and I a sheep?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Why then, my horns are his horns,
whether I
wake or sleep.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p:
A silly answer and fitting well a
sheep.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: This proves me still a sheep.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: True; and thy master a shepherd.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Nay, that I can deny by a circumstance.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p:
It shall go hard but I'll prove it by
another.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
The shepherd seeks the sheep, and
not the
sheep the shepherd; but I seek my
master, and my master seeks not me: therefore
I am no sheep.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p:
The sheep for fodder follow the shepherd;


the shepherd for food follows not the

sheep: thou 
for wages followest thy master;

thy master for wages 
follows not thee: therefore

thou art a sheep.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Such another proof will make me
cry 'baa.'

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p:
But, dost thou hear? gavest thou my
letter
to Julia?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Ay, sir: I, a lost mutton, gave
your letter to her,
a laced mutton, and she, a
laced mutton, gave me, a
lost mutton, nothing
for my labor.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p:
Here's too small a pasture for such
store of
muttons.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
If the ground be overcharged, you
were best
stick her.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p:
Nay: in that you are astray, 'twere
best pound
you.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Nay, sir, less than a pound shall
serve me for carrying
your letter.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p:
You mistake; I mean the pound,--a
pinfold.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: From a pound to a pin? fold it over and over.
'Tis threefold too little for carrying a letter to
your lover.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: But what said she?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Ay.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Nod--Ay--why, that's noddy.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
You mistook, sir; I say, she did
nod:
and you ask me if she did nod; and I
say, 'Ay.'

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: And that set together is noddy.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Now you have taken the pains to
set it together,
take it for your pains.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p:
No, no; you shall have it for bearing
the letter.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Well, I perceive I must be fain to
bear with you.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Why, sir, how do you bear with me?

sp.speaker: Speed.
Pro.
sp.p:
Beshrew me, but you have a quick
wit.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
And yet it cannot overtake your
slow purse.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p:
Come, come, open the matter in
brief: what
said she?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Open your purse, that the money
and the matter
may be both at once delivered.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Well, sir, here is for your pains.
sp.l: What said she?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Truly, sir, I think you'll hardly win
her.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p:
Why, couldst thou perceive so much
from her?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Sir, I could perceive nothing at all
from her;
no, not so much as a ducat for delivering
your letter:
and being so hard to me
that brought your mind,
I fear she'll prove as
hard to you in telling your mind.
Give her
no token but stones; for she's as hard as steel.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: What said she? nothing?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
No, not so much as 'Take this for
thy pains.'
To testify your bounty, I thank
you, you have testerned me;
in requital
whereof, henceforth carry your letters yourself:
and so, sir, I'll commend you to my
master.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Go, go, be gone, to save your ship from wreck,
Which cannot perish having thee aboard,
Being destined to a drier death on shore. [Exit Speed.
I must go send some better messenger:
I fear my Julia would not deign my lines,
Receiving them from such a worthless post. [Exit.

div2.head: SCENE II
div2.stage: The same. Garden of JULIA'S house.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: But say, Lucetta, now we are alone,
Wouldst thou then counsel me to fall in love?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Ay, madam, so you stumble not unheedfully.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Of all the fair resort of gentlemen
That every day with parle encounter me,
In thy opinion which is worthiest love?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Please you repeat their names, I'll show my mind
According to my shallow simple skill.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What think'st thou of the fair Sir Eglamour?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: As of a knight well-spoken, neat and fine;
But, were I you, he never should be mine.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What think'st thou of the rich Mercatio?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Well of his wealth; but of himself, so so.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What think'st thou of the gentle Proteus?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Lord, Lord! to see what folly reigns in us!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l:
How now! what means this passion
at his name?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Pardon, dear madam: 'tis a passing shame
That I, unworthy body as I am,
Should censure thus on lovely gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why not on Proteus, as of all the rest?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then thus: of many good I think him best.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Your reason?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I have no other but a woman's reason;
I think him so because I think him so.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And wouldst thou have me cast my love on him?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Ay, if you thought your love not cast away.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why he, of all the rest, hath never moved me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Yet he, of all the rest, I think, best loves ye.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: His little speaking shows his love but small.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Fire that's closest kept burns most of all.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: They do not love that do not show their love.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O, they love least that let men know their love.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I would I knew his mind.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Peruse this paper, madam.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'To Julia.' Say, from whom?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: That the contents will show.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Say, say, who gave it thee?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sir Valentine's page; and sent, I think, from Proteus.
He would have given it you; but I, being in the way,
Did in your name receive it: pardon the fault I pray.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Now, by my modesty, a goodly broker!
Dare you presume to harbor wanton lines?
To whisper and conspire against my youth?
Now, trust me, 'tis an office of great worth
And you an officer fit for the place.
There, take the paper: see it be return'd;
Or else return no more into my sight.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: To plead for love deserves more fee than hate.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Will ye be gone?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: That you may ruminate. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And yet I would I had overlooked the letter:
It were a shame to call her back again
And pray her to a fault for which I chid her.
What a fool is she, that knows I am a maid,
And would not force the letter to my view!
Since maids, in modesty, say 'no' to that
Which they would have the profferer construe 'ay.'
Fie, fie, how wayward is this foolish love
That, like a testy babe, will scratch the nurse
And presently all humbled kiss the rod!
How churlishly I chid Lucetta hence,
When willingly I would have had her here!
How angerly I taught my brow to frown,
When inward joy enforced my heart to smile!
My penance is to call Lucetta back
And ask remission for my folly past.
What ho! Lucetta! Re-enter LUCETTA.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What would your ladyship?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Is't near dinner-time?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I would it were,
That you might kill your stomach on your meat
And not upon your maid.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l:
What is't that you
took up so gingerly?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why didst thou stoop, then?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: To take a paper up that I let fall.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And is that paper nothing?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nothing concerning me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Then let it lie for those that it concerns.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Madam, it will not lie where it concerns,
Unless it have a false interpreter.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Some love of yours hath writ to you in rhyme.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: That I might sing it, madam, to a tune.
Give me a note: your ladyship can set.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: As little by such toys as may be possible.
Best sing it to the tune of 'Light o' love.'

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It is too heavy for so light a tune.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Heavy! belike it hath some burden then?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Ay, and melodious were it, would you sing it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And why not you?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I cannot reach so high.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l:
Let's see your song.
How now, minion!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Keep tune there still, so you will sing it out:
And yet methinks I do not like this tune.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You do not?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: No, madam; it is too sharp.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You, minion, are too saucy.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nay, now you are too flat
And mar the concord with too harsh a descant:
There wanteth but a mean to fill your song.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The mean is drown'd with your unruly bass.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Indeed, I bid the base for Proteus.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: This babble shall not henceforth trouble me.
Here is a coil with protestation! [Tears the letter.
Go get you gone, and let the papers lie:
You would be fingering them, to anger me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: She makes it strange; but she would be best pleased
To be so anger'd with another letter. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Nay, would I were so anger'd with the same!
O hateful hands, to tear such loving words!
Injurious wasps, to feed on such sweet honey
And kill the bees that yield it with your stings!
I'll kiss each several paper for amends.
Look, here is writ 'kind Julia.' Unkind Julia!
As in revenge of thy ingratitude,
I throw thy name against the bruising stones,
Trampling contemptuously on thy disdain.
And here is writ 'love-wounded Proteus.'
Poor wounded name! my bosom as a bed
Shall lodge thee till thy wound be throughly heal'd;
And thus I search it with a sovereign kiss.
But twice or thrice was 'Proteus' written down.
Be calm, good wind, blow not a word away
Till I have found each letter in the letter,
Except mine own name: that some whirlwind bear
Unto a ragged fearful-hanging rock
And throw it thence into the raging sea!
Lo, here in one line is his name twice writ,
'Poor forlorn Proteus, passionate Proteus,
To the sweet Julia:' that I'll tear away.
And yet I will not, sith so prettily
He couples it to his complaining names.
Thus will I fold them one upon another:

Now kiss, embrace, contend, do what you will.
Re-enter LUCETTA.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Madam,
Dinner is ready, and your father stays.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Well, let us go.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What, shall these papers lie like tell-tales here?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: If you respect them, best to take them up.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nay, I was taken up for laying them down:
Yet here they shall not lie, for catching cold.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I see you have a month's mind to them.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Ay, madam, you may say what sights you see;
I see things too, although you judge I wink.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Come, come; will't please you go? [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Tell me, Panthino, what sad talk was that
Wherewith my brother held you in the cloister?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: 'Twas of his nephew Proteus, your son.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why, what of him?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: He wonder'd that your lordship
Would suffer him to spend his youth at home,
While other men, of slender reputation,
Put forth their sons to seek preferment out:
Some of the wars, to try their fortune there;
Some to discover islands far away;
Some to the studious universities.
For any or for all these exercises
He said that Proteus your son was meet,
And did request me to importune you
To let him spend his time no more at home,
Which would be great impeachment to his age,
In having known no travel in his youth.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nor need'st thou much importune me to that
Whereon this month I have been hammering.
I have consider'd well his loss of time
And how he cannot be a perfect man,
Not being tried and tutor'd in the world:
Experience is by industry achieved
And perfected by the swift course of time.
Then tell me, whither were I best to send him?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I think your lordship is not ignorant
How his companion, youthful Valentine,
Attends the emperor in his royal court.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I know it well.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: 'Twere good, I think, your lordship sent him thither:
There shall he practise tilts and tournaments,
Hear sweet discourse, converse with noblemen,
And be in eye of every exercise
Worthy his youth and nobleness of birth.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I like thy counsel; well hast thou advised:
And that thou mayst perceive how well I like it
The execution of it shall make known.
Even with the speediest expedition
I will dispatch him to the emperor's court.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: To-morrow, may it please you, Don Alphonso,
With other gentlemen of good esteem
Are journeying to salute the emperor
And to commend their service to his will.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Good company; with them shall Proteus go:
And, in good time now will we break with him. Enter PROTEUS.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Sweet love! sweet lines! sweet life!
Here is her hand, the agent of her heart;
Here is her oath for love, her honor's pawn.
O, that our fathers would applaud our loves,
To seal our happiness with their consents!
O heavenly Julia!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How now! what letter are you reading there?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: May't please your lordship, 'tis a word or two
Of commendations sent from Valentine,
Deliver'd by a friend that came from him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Lend me the letter; let me see what news.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: There is no news, my lord, but that he writes
How happily he lives, how well beloved
And daily graced by the emperor;
Wishing me with him, partner of his fortune.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And how stand you affected to his wish?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: As one relying on your lordship's will
And not depending on his friendly wish.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My will is something sorted with his wish.
Muse not that I thus suddenly proceed;
For what I will, I will, and there an end.
I am resolved that thou shalt spend some time
With Valentinus in the emperor's court:
What maintenance he from his friends receives,
Like exhibition thou shalt have from me.
To-morrow be in readiness to go:
Excuse it not, for I am peremptory.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: My lord, I cannot be so soon provided:
Please you, deliberate a day or two.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Look, what thou want'st shall be sent after thee:
No more of stay! to-morrow thou must go.
Come on, Panthino: you shall be employ'd

To hasten on his expedition.
Exeunt Ant. and Pan.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Thus have I shunn'd the fire for fear of burning,
And drench'd me in the sea, where I am drown'd.
I fear'd to show my father Julia's letter,
Lest he should take exceptions to my love;
And with the vantage of mine own excuse
Hath he excepted most against my love.
O, how this spring of love resembleth
The uncertain glory of an April day,
Which now shows all the beauty of the sun,
And by and by a cloud takes all away! Re-enter PANTHINO.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Sir Proteus, your father calls for you,
He is in haste; therefore, I pray you, go.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Why, this it is: my heart accords thereto,

And yet a thousand times it answers 'no.'
Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Sir, your glove.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not mine; my gloves are on.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l:
Why, then, this may be yours, for
this is but one.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l:
Ha! let me see: ay, give it me, it's
mine:
Sweet ornament that decks a thing divine!
Ah, Silvia, Silvia!

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Madam Silvia! Madam Silvia!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How now, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: She is not within hearing, sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why, sir, who bade you call her?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Your worship, sir; or else I mistook.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Well, you'll still be too forward.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
And yet I was last chidden for being
too slow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Go to, sir: tell me, do you know
Madam Silvia?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: She that your worship loves?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Why, how know you that I am in
love?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Marry, by these special marks:
first, you have
learned, like Sir Proteus, to
wreathe your arms, like a
malecontent; to relish
a love-song, like a robin-redbreast;
to
walk alone, like one that had the pestilence;
to sigh, like a schoolboy that had lost his
A B C;
to weep, like a young wench that had
buried her grandam;
to fast, like one that
takes diet; to watch, like one that
fears robbing;
to speak puling, like a beggar at Hallowmas.
You were wont, when you laughed,
to crow
like a cock; when you walked, to
walk like one of the
lions; when you fasted,
it was presently after dinner;
when you
looked sadly, it was for want of money: and
now
you are metamorphosed with a mistress, that,
when I
look on you, I can hardly think you
my master.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And all these things perceived in me?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: They are all perceived without ye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Without me? they cannot.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Without you? nay, that's certain,
for, without
you were so simple, none else
would: but you are
so without these follies,
that these follies are within you
and shine
through you like the water in an urinal, that
not an eye that sees you but is a physician to
comment
on your malady.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
But tell me, dost thou know my lady
Silvia?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
She that you gaze on so as she sits
at supper?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Hast thou observed that? even she, I
mean.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Why, sir, I know her not.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Dost thou know her by my gazing on
her, and
yet knowest her not?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Is she not hard-favored, sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not so fair, boy, as well-favored.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Sir, I know that well enough.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What dost thou know?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
That she is not so fair as, of you,
well favored.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
I mean that her beauty is exquisite,
but her favor infinite.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
That 's because the one is painted
and the other
out of all count.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
How painted? and how out of
count?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Marry, sir, so painted, to make her
fair, that no
man counts of her beauty.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
How esteemest thou me? I account
of her beauty.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
You never saw her since she was
deformed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How long hath she been deformed?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Ever since you loved her.

sp.speaker: Val.
Speed.
sp.l:
If you love her, you cannot see
her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Because Love is blind. O, that you
had mine
eyes; or your own eyes had the
lights they were wont
to have when you chid
at Sir Proteus for going
ungartered!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What should I see then?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Your own present folly and her
passing deformity:
for he, being in love,
could not see to garter
his hose, and you, being
in love, cannot see to put on
your hose.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Belike, boy, then, you are in love;

for last morning 
you could not see to wipe

my shoes.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
True, sir; I was in love with my
bed: I thank
you, you swinged me for my
love, which makes me the
bolder to chide
you for yours.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l:
In conclusion, I stand affected to
her.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l:
I would you were set, so your affection
would
cease.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Last night she enjoined me
to write
some lines to one she loves.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: And have you?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I have.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Are they not lamely writ?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No, boy, but as well as I can do them.
Peace! here she comes.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l:
O excellent motion! O exceeding
puppet!
Now will he interpret to her. Enter SILVIA.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l:
Madam and mistress, a thousand
good-morrows.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
O, give ye good even!
here's a million of
manners.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l:
Sir Valentine and servant, to you
two thousand.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
He should give her interest,
and she gives it him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: As you enjoin'd me, I have writ your letter
Unto the secret nameless friend of yours;
Which I was much unwilling to proceed in
But for my duty to your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l:
I thank you, gentle servant: 'tis very
clerkly done.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Now trust me, madam, it came hardly off;
For being ignorant to whom it goes
I writ at random, very doubtfully.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l:
Perchance you think too much of so
much pains?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No, madam; so it stead you, I will write,
Please you command, a thousand times as much;
And yet--

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: A pretty period! Well, I guess the sequel;
And yet I will not name it; and yet I care not;
And yet take this again; and yet I thank you,
Meaning henceforth to trouble you no more.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: And yet you will; and yet another 'yet.'

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l:
What means your ladyship?
do you not like it?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Yes, yes: the lines are very quaintly writ;
But since unwillingly, take them again.
Nay, take them.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Madam, they are for you.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Ay, ay: you writ them sir, at my request;
But I will none of them; they are for you;
I would have had them writ more movingly.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Please you, I'll write your ladyship another.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: And when it's writ, for my sake read it over,
And if it please you, so; if not, why, so.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: If it please me, madam, what then?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Why, if it please you, take it for your labor:
And so, good morrow, servant. Exit.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: O jest unseen, inscrutable, invisible,
As a nose on a man's face, or a weathercock on a steeple!
My master sues to her, and she hath taught her suitor,
He being her pupil, to become her tutor.
O excellent device! was there ever heard a better,

That my master, being scribe,
to himself
should write the letter?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
How now, sir?
what are you reasoning
with yourself?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Nay, I was rhyming: 'tis you that
have the reason.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: To do what?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
To be a spokesman from Madam
Silvia.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: To whom?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
To yourself: why, she wooes you
by a figure.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What figure?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: By a letter, I should say.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why, she hath not writ to me?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
What need she,
when she hath
made you write to yourself?
Why, do you not
perceive the jest?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No, believe me.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
No believing you, indeed, sir.
But
did you perceive her earnest?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
She gave me none, except an angry
word.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Why, she hath given you a letter.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That's the letter I writ to her friend.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
And that letter hath she delivered,
and there an end.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I would it were no worse.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: I'll warrant you, 'tis as well:
sp.l: For often have you writ to her, and she, in modesty,
Or else for want of idle time, could not again reply;
Or fearing else some messenger that might her mind discover,
Herself hath taught her love himself to write unto her lover.
All this I speak in print, for in print I found it.
Why muse you, sir? 'tis dinner-time.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I have dined.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Ay, but hearken, sir; though the
chameleon Love
can feed on the air, I am one
that am nourished by my
victuals, and would
fain have meat. O, be not like
your mistress;
be moved, be moved. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Have patience, gentle Julia.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I must, where is no remedy.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: When possibly I can, I will return.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: If you turn not, you will return the sooner.

Keep this remembrance for thy Julia's sake.
[Giving a ring.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l:
Why, then, we'll make exchange;
here, take you this.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And seal the bargain with a holy kiss.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Here is my hand for my true constancy;
And when that hour o'erslips me in the day
Wherein I sigh not, Julia, for thy sake,
The next ensuing hour some foul mischance
Torment me for my love's forgetfulness
My father stays my coming; answer not;
The tide is now: nay, not thy tide of tears;
That tide will stay me longer than I should.
Julia, farewell! [Exit Julia.
What, gone without a word?
Ay, so true love should do: it cannot speak;

For truth hath better deeds than words to
grace it. Enter PANTHINO.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Sir Proteus, you are stay'd for.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Go; I come, I come.

Alas! this parting strikes poor lovers dumb.
[Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Nay, 'twill be this hour ere I have
done
weeping; all the kind of the Launces
have this very
fault. I have received my proportion,
like the prodigious
son, and am going
with Sir Proteus to the Imperial's
court. I
think Crab my dog be the sourest-natured
dog that lives: my mother weeping, my father
wailing, my sister crying, our maid howling,
our
cat wringing her hands, and all our house
in a great
perplexity, yet did not this cruel-hearted
cur shed
one tear: he is a stone, a
very pebblestone, and has no
more pity in
him than a dog: a Jew would have wept
to
have seen our parting; why, my grandam,
having
no eyes, look you, wept herself blind
at my parting.
Nay, I'll show you the manner
of it. This shoe is my father:
no, this left shoe
is my father: no, no, this left
shoe is my
mother: nay, that cannot be so neither:
yes,
it is so, it is so, it hath the worser sole. This
shoe,
with the hole in it, is my mother, and
this my father;
a vengeance on't! there 'tis;
now, sir, this staff is my sister,
for, look you,
she is as white as a lily and as
small as a
wand: this hat is Nan, our maid: I am the
dog: no, the dog is himself, and I am the dog
--Oh! the dog is me, and I am myself; ay,
so, so. Now
come I to my father; Father,
your blessing: now
should not the shoe speak
a word for weeping:
now should I kiss my
father; well, he weeps on.
Now come I to my
mother: O, that she could speak
now like a
wood woman! Well, I kiss her; why,
there
'tis; here 's my mother's breath up and down.
Now come I to my sister; mark the moan she
makes.
Now the dog all this while sheds not a
tear nor
speaks a word; but see how I lay
the dust with my
tears. Enter PANTHINO.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Launce, away, away, aboard! thy
master is
shipped and thou art to post after
with oars. What's the
matter? why weepest
thou, man? Away, ass! you'll lose
the tide,
if you tarry any longer.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
It is no matter if the tied were
lost; for it is the
unkindest tied that ever any
man tied.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: What's the unkindest tide?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Why, he that's tied here, Crab,
my dog.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Tut, man, I mean thou'lt lose the
flood, and,
in losing the flood, lose thy voyage,
and, in losing thy
voyage, lose thy master, and,
in losing thy master,
lose thy service, and, in
losing thy service,--Why
dost thou stop my
mouth?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
For fear thou shouldst lose thy
tongue.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Where should I lose my tongue?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: In thy tale.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: In thy tail!

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Lose the tide, and the voyage, and
the master,
and the service, and the tied!
Why, man, if the river
were dry, I am able to
fill it with my tears; if the wind
were down, I
could drive the boat with my sighs.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Come, come away, man; I was sent
to call
thee.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Sir, call me what thou darest.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Wilt thou go?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Well, I will go.
[Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE IV
div2.stage: Enter SILVIA, VALENTINE, THURIO, and SPEED.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Servant!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Mistress?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Master, Sir Thurio frowns on you,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Ay, boy, it's for love.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Not of you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Of my mistress, then.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: 'Twere good you knocked him. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Servant, you are sad.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Indeed, madam, I seem so.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: Seem you that you are not?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Haply I do.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: So do counterfeits.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: So do you.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: What seem I that I am not?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Wise.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: What instance of the contrary?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Your folly.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: And how quote you my folly?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I quote it in your jerkin.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: My jerkin is a doublet.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Well, then, I'll double your folly.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p:
What, angry, Sir Thurio! do you
change color?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Give him leave, madam; he is a kind
of chameleon.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p:
That hath more mind to feed on
your blood
than live in your air.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You have said, sir.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p:
Ay, sir, and done too, for this
time.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
I know it well, sir; you always end
ere you begin.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p:
A fine volley of words, gentlemen, and
quickly shot off.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
'Tis indeed, madam; we thank the
giver.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Who is that, servant?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Yourself, sweet lady; for you gave
the fire.
Sir Thurio borrows his wit from your
ladyship's looks,
and spends what he borrows
kindly in your company.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p:
Sir, if you spend word for word
with me, I shall
make your wit bankrupt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
I know it well, sir; you have an exchequer
of words,
and, I think, no other treasure
to give your followers,
for it appears by
their bare liveries,
that they live by your bare
words.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p:
No more, gentlemen, no more:
here comes my father. Enter DUKE.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Now, daughter Silvia, you are hard beset.
Sir Valentine, your father's in good health:
What say you to a letter from your friends
Of much good news?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My lord, I will be thankful
To any happy messenger from thence.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Know ye Don Antonio, your countryman ?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ay, my good lord, I know the gentleman
To be of worth and worthy estimation
And not without desert so well reputed.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Hath he not a son?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ay, my good lord; a son that well deserves
The honor and regard of such a father.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You know him well?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I know him as myself; for from our infancy
We have conversed and spent our hours together;
And though myself have been an idle truant,
Omitting the sweet benefit of time
To clothe mine age with angel-like perfection,
Yet hath Sir Proteus, for that's his name,
Made use and fair advantage of his days;
His years but young, but his experience old;
His head unmellow'd, but his judgement ripe;
And, in a word, for far behind his worth
Comes all the praises that I now bestow,
He is complete in feature and in mind
With all good grace to grace a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Beshrew me, sir, but if he make this good,
He is as worthy for an empress' love
As meet to be an emperor's counsellor.
Well, sir, this gentleman is come to me,
With commendation from great potentates;
And here he means to spend his time awhile:
I think 'tis no unwelcome news to you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Should I have wish'd a thing, it had been he.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Welcome him then according to his worth.
Silvia, I speak to you, and you, Sir Thurio;
For Valentine, I need not cite him to it;
I will send him hither to you presently. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This is the gentleman I told your ladyship
Had come along with me, but that his mistress
Did hold his eyes lock'd in her crystal looks.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Belike that now she hath enfranchised them
Upon some other pawn for fealty.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nay, sure, I think she holds them prisoners still.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Nay, then he should be blind; and, being blind,
How could he see his way to seek out you?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why, lady, Love hath twenty pair of eyes.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: They say that Love hath not an eye at all.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: To see such lovers, Thurio, as yourself:
Upon a homely object Love can wink.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Have done, have done; here comes the gentleman. [Exit THURIO. Enter PROTEUS

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Welcome, dear Proteus! Mistress, I beseech you,
Confirm his welcome with some special favor.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: His worth is warrant for his welcome hither,
If this be he you oft have wish'd to hear from.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Mistress, it is: sweet lady, entertain him
To be my fellow-servant to your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Too low a mistress for so high a servant.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Not so, sweet lady: but too mean a servant
To have a look of such a worthy mistress.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Leave off discourse of disability:
Sweet lady, entertain him for your servant.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: My duty will I boast of; nothing else.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: And duty never yet did want his meed:
Servant, you are welcome to a worthless mistress.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I'll die on him that says so but yourself.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: That you are welcome?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: That you are worthless. Re-enter THURIO.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: Madam, my lord your father would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I wait upon his pleasure. Come, Sir Thurio,
Go with me. Once more, new servant, welcome:
I'll leave you to confer of home affairs;
When you have done, we look to hear from you.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: We'll both attend upon your ladyship. [Exeunt Silvia and Thurio.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Now, tell me, how do all from whence you came?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Your friends are well and have them much commended.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And how do yours?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I left them all in health.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How does your lady? and how thrives your love?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: My tales of love were wont to weary you;
I know you joy not in a love-discourse.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ay, Proteus, but that life is alter'd now:
I have done penance for contemning Love,
Whose high imperious thoughts have punish'd me
With bitter fasts, with penitential groans,
With nightly tears and daily heart-sore sighs;
For in revenge of my contempt of love,
Love hath chased sleep from my enthralled eyes
And made them watchers of mine own heart's sorrow.
O gentle Proteus, Love's a mighty lord
And hath so humbled me as I confess
This is no woe to his correction
Nor to his service no such joy on earth.
Now no discourse, except it be of love;
Now can I break my fast, dine, sup and sleep,
Upon the very naked name of love.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Enough; I read your fortune in your eye.
Was this the idol that you worship so?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Even she; and is she not a heavenly saint?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: No; but she is an earthly paragon.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Call her divine.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I will not flatter her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O, flatter me; for love delights in praises.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: When I was sick, you gave me bitter pills,
And I must minister the like to you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Then speak the truth by her; if not divine,
Yet let her be a principality,
Sovereign to all the creatures on the earth.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Except my mistress.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sweet, except not any;
Except thou wilt except against my love.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Have I not reason to prefer mine own?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And I will help thee to prefer her too:
She shall be dignified with this high honor--
To bear my lady's train, lest the base earth
Should from her vesture chance to steal a kiss
And, of so great a favor growing proud,
Disdain to root the summer-swelling flower
And make rough winter everlastingly.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Why, Valentine, what braggardism is this?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Pardon me, Proteus: all I can is nothing
To her whose worth makes other worthies nothing;
She is alone.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Then let her alone.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not for the world: why, man, she is mine own,
And I as rich in having such a jewel
As twenty seas, if all their sand were pearl,
The water nectar and the rocks pure gold.
Forgive me that I do not dream on thee,
Because thou see'st me dote upon my love.
My foolish rival, that her father likes
Only for his possessions are so huge,
Is gone with her along, and I must after,
For love, thou know'st, is full of jealousy.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: But she loves you?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ay, and we are betroth'd: nay, more, our marriage-hour,
With all the cunning manner of our flight,
Determined of; how I must climb her window,
The ladder made of cords, and all the means
Plotted and 'greed on for my happiness.
Good Proteus, go with me to my chamber,
In these affairs to aid me with thy counsel.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Go on before; I shall inquire you forth:
I must unto the road, to disembark
Some necessaries that I needs must use,
And then I'll presently attend you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Will you make haste?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I will. [Exit Valentine.
Even as one heat another heat expels,
Or as one nail by strength drives out another,
So the remembrance of my former love
Is by a newer object quite forgotten.
Is it mine, or Valentine's praise,
Her true perfection, or my false transgression,
That makes me reasonless to reason thus?
She is fair; and so is Julia that I love--
That I did love, for now my love is thaw'd;
Which, like a waxen image 'gainst a fire,
Bears no impression of the thing it was.
Methinks my zeal to Valentine is cold,
And that I love him not as I was wont.
O, but I love his lady too too much,
And that's the reason I love him so little.
How shall I dote on her with more advice,
That thus without advice begin to love her!
'Tis but her picture I have yet beheld,
And that hath dazzled my reason's light;
But when I look on her perfections,
There is no reason but I shall be blind.
If I can check my erring love, I will:

If not, to compass her I'll use my skill.
[Exit.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Launce! by mine honesty, welcome
to Milan!

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Forswear not thyself, sweet youth,
for I am
not welcome. I reckon this always,
that a man is never
undone till he be hanged,
nor never welcome to a place
till some certain
shot be paid and the hostess say
'Welcome!'

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Come on, you madcap, I'll to the
alehouse
with you presently; where, for one
shot of five pence,
thou shalt have five thousand
welcomes. But, sirrah, how
did thy
master part with Madam Julia?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Marry, after they closed in earnest,
they parted
very fairly in jest.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: But shall she marry him?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: How then? shall he marry her?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: No, neither.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: What, are they broken?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
No, they are both as whole as a
fish.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Why, then, how stands the matter
with them?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Marry, thus; when it stands well
with him, it
stands well with her.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
What an ass art thou! I understand
thee not.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
What a block art thou, that thou
canst not!
My staff understands me.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: What thou sayest?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Ay, and what I do too: look thee,
I'll but lean,
and my staff understands me.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: It stands under thee, indeed.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Why, stand-under and understand
is all one.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: But tell me true, will 't be a match?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Ask my dog: if he say ay, it will!
if he say
no, it will; if he shake his tail and
say nothing, it
will.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: The conclusion is then that it will.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Thou shalt never get such a secret
from me but
by a parable.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
'Tis well that I get it so. But,
Launce, how sayest
thou, that my master is
become a notable lover?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: I never knew him otherwise.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Than how?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
A notable lubber, as thou reportest
him to
be.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Why, thou whoreson ass, thou mistakest
me.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Why, fool, I meant not thee; I
meant thy
master.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
I tell thee, my master is become a
hot lover.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Why, I tell thee, I care not though
he burn
himself in love. If thou wilt, go with
me to the alehouse;
if not, thou art an Hebrew,
a Jew, and not worth
the name of a
Christian.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Because thou hast not so much
charity in thee as
to go to the ale with a
Christian. Wilt thou go?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
At thy service.
[Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: To leave my Julia, shall I be forsworn;
To love fair Silvia, shall I be forsworn;
To wrong my friend, I shall be much forsworn;
And even that power which gave me first my oath
Provokes me to this threefold perjury;
Love bade me swear and Love bids me forswear.
O sweet-suggesting Love, if thou hast sinn'd,
Teach me, thy tempted subject, to excuse it!
At first I did adore a twinkling star,
But now I worship a celestial sun.
Unheedful vows may heedfully be broken,
And he wants wit that wants resolved will
To learn his wit to exchange the bad for better.
Fie, fie, unreverend tongue! to call her bad,
Whose sovereignty so oft thou hast preferr'd
With twenty thousand soul-confirming oaths.
I cannot leave to love, and yet I do;
But there I leave to love where I should love.
Julia I lose and Valentine I lose:
If I keep them, I needs must lose myself;
If I lose them, thus find I by their loss
For Valentine myself, for Julia Silvia.
I to myself am dearer than a friend,
For love is still most precious in itself;
And Silvia--witness Heaven, that made her fair!--
Shows Julia but a swarthy Ethiope.
I will forget that Julia is alive,
Remembering that my love to her is dead;
And Valentine I'll hold an enemy,
Aiming at Silvia as a sweeter friend.
I cannot now prove constant to myself,
Without some treachery used to Valentine.
This night he meaneth with a corded ladder
To climb celestial Silvia's chamber-window,
Myself in counsel, his competitor.
Now presently I'll give her father notice
Of their disguising and pretended flight;
Who, all enraged, will banish Valentine;
For Thurio, he intends, shall wed his daughter;
But, Valentine being gone, I'll quickly cross
By some sly trick blunt Thurio's dull proceeding.
Love, lend me wings to make my purpose swift,

As thou hast lent me wit to plot this drift!
[Exit.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Counsel, Lucetta; gentle girl, assist me;
And even in kind love I do conjure thee,
Who art the table wherein all my thoughts
Are visibly character'd and engraved,
To lesson me and tell me some good mean
How, with my honour, I may undertake
A journey to my loving Proteus.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Alas, the way is wearisome and long!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: A true-devoted pilgrim is not weary
To measure kingdoms with his feeble steps;
Much less shall she that hath Love's wings to fly,
And when the flight is made to one so dear,
Of such divine perfection, as Sir Proteus.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Better forbear till Proteus make return.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O, know'st thou not his looks are my soul's food?
Pity the dearth that I have pined in,
By longing for that food so long a time.
Didst thou but know the inly touch of love,
Thou wouldst as soon go kindle fire with snow
As seek to quench the fire of love with words.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I do not seek to quench your love's hot fire,
But qualify the fire's extreme rage,
Lest it should burn above the bounds of reason.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The more thou damm'st it up, the more it burns.
The current that with gentle murmur glides,
Thou know'st, being stopp'd, impatiently doth rage;
But when his fair course is not hindered,
He makes sweet music with the enamell'd stones,
Giving a gentle kiss to every sedge
He overtaketh in his pilgrimage,
And so by many winding nooks he strays
With willing sport to the wild ocean.
Then let me go and hinder not my course:
I'll be as patient as a gentle stream
And make a pastime of each weary step,
Till the last step have brought me to my love;
And there I'll rest, as after much turmoil
A blessed soul doth in Elysium.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But in what habit will you go along?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Not like a woman; for I would prevent
The loose encounters of lascivious men:
Gentle Lucetta, fit me with such weeds
As may beseem some well-reputed page.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Why, then, your ladyship must cut your hair.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: No, girl; I'll knit it up in silken strings
With twenty odd-conceited true-love knots.
To be fantastic may become a youth
Of greater time than I shall show to be.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What fashion, madam, shall I make your breeches?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: That fits as well as 'Tell me, good my lord,
What compass will you wear your farthingale?'
Why even what fashion thou best likest, Lucetta.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You must needs have them with a codpiece, madam.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Out, out, Lucetta! that will be ill-favor'd.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: A round hose, madam, now's not worth a pin,
Unless you have a codpiece to stick pins on.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Lucetta, as thou lovest me, let me have
What thou thinkest meet and is most mannerly.
But tell me, wench, how will the world repute me
For undertaking so unstaid a journey?
I fear me, it will make me scandalized.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: If you think so, then stay at home and go not.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Nay, that I will not.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then never dream on infamy, but go.
If Proteus like your journey when you come,
No matter who's displeased when you are gone:
I fear me, he will scarce be pleased withal.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: That is the least, Lucetta, of my fear:
A thousand oaths, an ocean of his tears
And instances of infinite of love
Warrant me welcome to my Proteus.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: All these are servants to deceitful men.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Base men, that use them to so base effect!
But truer stars did govern Proteus' birth;
His words are bonds, his oaths are oracles,
His love sincere, his thoughts immaculate,
His tears pure messengers sent from his heart,
His heart as far from fraud as heaven from earth.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Pray heaven he prove so, when you come to him!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Now, as thou lovest me, do him not that wrong
To bear a hard opinion of his truth:
Only deserve my love by loving him;
And presently go with me to my chamber,
To take a note of what I stand in need of,
To furnish me upon my longing journey.
All that is mine I leave at thy dispose,
My goods, my lands, my reputation;
Only, in lieu thereof, dispatch me hence.
Come, answer not, but to it presently!

I am impatient of my tarriance.
[Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Sir Thurio, give us leave, I pray, awhile;
We have some secrets to confer about. [Exit Thu.
Now, tell me, Proteus, what's your will with me?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: My gracious lord, that which would discover
The law of friendship bids me to conceal;
But when I call to mind your gracious favours
Done to me, undeserving as I am,
My duty pricks me on to utter that
Which else no worldly good should draw from me.
Know, worthy prince, Sir Valentine, my friend,
This night intends to steal away your daughter:
Myself am one made privy to the plot.
I know you have determined to bestow her
On Thurio, whom your gentle daughter hates;
And should she thus be stol'n away from you,
It would be much vexation to your age.
Thus, for my duty's sake, I rather chose
To cross my friend in his intended drift
Than, by concealing it, heap on your head
A pack of sorrows which would press you down,
Being unprevented, to your timeless grave.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Proteus, I thank thee for thine honest care;
Which to requite, command me while I live.
This love of theirs myself have often seen,
Haply when they have judged me fast asleep,
And oftentimes have purposed to forbid
Sir Valentine her company and my court:
But fearing lest my jealous aim might err
And so unworthily disgrace the man,
A rashness that I ever yet have shunn'd,
I gave him gentle looks, thereby to find
That which thyself hast now disclosed to me.
And, that thou mayest perceive my fear of this,
Knowing that tender youth is soon suggested,
I nightly lodge her in an upper tower,
The key whereof myself have ever kept;
And thence she cannot be convey'd away.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Know, noble lord, they have devised a mean
How he her chamber-window will ascend
And with a corded ladder fetch her down;
For which the youthful lover now is gone
And this way comes he with it presently;
Where, if it please you, you may intercept him.
But, good my lord, do it so cunningly
That my discovery be not aimed at;
For love of you, not hate unto my friend,
Hath made me publisher of this pretence.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Upon mine honour, he shall never know
That I had any light from thee of this.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Adieu, my lord; Sir Valentine is coming. [Exit. Enter VALENTINE.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Sir Valentine, whither away so fast?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Please it your grace, there is a messenger
That stays to bear my letters to my friends,
And I am going to deliver them.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Be they of much import?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The tenor of them doth but signify
My health and happy being at your court.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Nay then, no matter; stay with me awhile;
I am to break with thee of some affairs
That touch me near, wherein thou must be secret.
'Tis not unknown to thee that I have sought
To match my friend Sir Thurio to my daughter.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I know it well, my lord; and, sure, the match
Were rich and honorable; besides, the gentleman
Is full of virtue, bounty, worth and qualities
Beseeming such a wife as your fair daughter:
Cannot your grace win her to fancy him?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: No, trust me; she is peevish, sullen, froward,
Proud, disobedient, stubborn, lacking duty,
Neither regarding that she is my child
Nor fearing me as if I were her father;
And, may I say to thee, this pride of hers,
Upon advice, hath drawn my love from her;
And, where I thought the remnant of mine age
Should have been cherish'd by her child-like duty,
I now am full resolved to take a wife
And turn her out to who will take her in:
Then let her beauty be her wedding-dower;
For me and my possessions she esteems not.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What would your grace have me to do in this?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: There is a lady in Verona here
Whom I affect; but she is nice and coy
And nought esteems my aged eloquence:
Now therefore would I have thee to my tutor--
For long agone I have forgot to court;
Besides, the fashion of the time is changed--
How and which way I may bestow myself
To be regarded in her sun-bright eye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Win her with gifts, if she respect not words:
Dumb jewels often in their silent kind
More than quick words do move a woman's mind.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But she did scorn a present that I sent her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A woman sometimes scorns what best contents her.
Send her another; never give her o'er;
For scorn at first makes after-love the more.
If she do frown, 'tis not in hate of you,
But rather to beget more love in you:
If she do chide, 'tis not to have you gone;
For why, the fools are mad, if left alone.
Take no repulse, whatever she doth say;
For 'get you gone,' she doth not mean 'away!'
Flatter and praise, commend, extol their graces;
Though ne'er so black, say they have angels' faces.
That man that hath a tongue, I say, is no man,
If with his tongue he cannot win a woman.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But she I mean is promised by her friends
Unto a youthful gentleman of worth,
And kept severely from resort of men,
That no man hath access by day to her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why, then, I would resort to her by night.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Ay, but the doors be lock'd and keys kept safe,
That no man hath recourse to her by night.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What lets but one may enter at her window?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Her chamber is aloft, far from the ground,
And built so shelving that one cannot climb it
Without apparent hazard of his life.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why then, a ladder quaintly made of cords,
To cast up, with a pair of anchoring hooks,
Would serve to scale another Hero's tower,
So bold Leander would adventure it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Now, as thou art a gentleman of blood,
Advise me where I may have such a ladder.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: When would you use it? pray, sir, tell me that.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: This very night; for Love is like a child,
That longs for everything that he can come by.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: By seven o'clock I'll get you such a ladder.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But, hark thee; I will go to her alone:
How shall I best convey the ladder thither?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It will be light, my lord, that you may bear it
Under a cloak that is of any length.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: A cloak as long as thine will serve the turn?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ay, my good lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Then let me see thy cloak:
I'll get me one of such another length.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why, any cloak will serve the turn, my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How shall I fashion me to wear a cloak?
I pray thee, let me feel thy cloak upon me.
What letter is this same? What's here? 'To Silvia'!
And here an engine fit for my proceeding.
I'll be so bold to break the seal for once. [Reads.
'My thoughts do harbor with my Silvia nightly.
And slaves they are to me that send them flying:
O, could their master come and go as lightly,
Himself would lodge where senseless they are lying!
My herald thoughts in thy pure bosom rest them;
While I, their king, that hither them importune,
Do curse the grace that with such grace hath bless'd them,
Because myself do want my servants' fortune:
I curse myself, for they are sent by me,
That they should harbour where their lord would be.'
What's here?
'Silvia, this night I will enfranchise thee.'
'Tis so; and here's the ladder for the purpose.
Why, Phaethon,--for thou art Merops' son,--
Wilt thou aspire to guide the heavenly car
And with thy daring folly burn the world?
Wilt thou reach stars, because they shine on thee?
Go, base intruder! overweening slave!
Bestow thy fawning smiles on equal mates,
And think my patience, more than thy desert,
Is privilege for thy departure hence:
Thank me for this more than for all the favours
Which all too much I have bestow'd on thee.
But if thou linger in my territories
Longer than swiftest expedition
Will give thee time to leave our royal court,
By heaven! my wrath shall far exceed the love
I ever bore my daughter or thyself.
Be gone! I will not hear thy vain excuse;
But, as thou lovest thy life, make speed from hence. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And why not death rather than living torment?
To die is to be banish'd from myself;
And Silvia is myself: banish'd from her
Is self from self: a deadly banishment!
What light is light, if Silvia be not seen?
What joy is joy if Silvia be not by?
Unless it be to think that she is by
And feed upon the shadow of perfection.
Except I be by Silvia in the night,
There is no music in the nightingale;
Unless I look on Silvia in the day,
There is no day for me to look upon;
She is my essence, and I leave to be,
If I be not by her fair influence
Foster'd, illumined, cherish'd, kept alive.
I fly not death, to fly his deadly doom:
Tarry I here, I but attend on death:
But, fly I hence, I fly away from life. Enter PROTEUS and LAUNCE.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Run, boy, run, run, and seek him out.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Soho, soho!

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: What seest thou?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Him we go to find:
there's not a
hair on 's head but 'tis a Valentine.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Valentine?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Who then? his spirit?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Neither.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.l: Can nothing speak? Master, shall I strike?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Who wouldst thou strike?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Villain, forbear.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.l: Why, sir, I'll strike nothing: I pray you,--

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Sirrah, I say, forbear. Friend Valentine, a word.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My ears are stopt and cannot hear good news,
So much of bad already hath possess'd them.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Then in dumb silence will I bury mine,
For they are harsh, untuneable and bad.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Is Silvia dead?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: No, Valentine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No Valentine, indeed, for sacred Silvia.
Hath she forsworn me?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: No, Valentine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No Valentine, if Silvia have forsworn me.
What is your news?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.l: Sir, there is a proclamation that you are vanished.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: That thou art banished--O, that's the news!--
From hence, from Silvia and from me thy friend.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O, I have fed upon this woe already,a
And now excess of it will make me surfeit.
Doth Silvia know that I am banished?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Ay, ay; and she hath offer'd to the doom--
Which, unreversed, stands in effectual force--
A sea of melting pearl, which some call tears:
Those at her father's churlish feet she tender'd;
With them, upon her knees, her humble self;
Wringing her hands, whose whiteness so became them
As if but now they waxed pale for woe:
But neither bended knees, pure hands held up,
Sad sighs, deep groans, nor silver-shedding tears,
Could penetrate her uncompassionate sire;
But Valentine, if he be ta'en, must die,
Besides, her intercession chafed him so,
When she for thy repeal was suppliant,
That to close prison he commanded her,
With many bitter threats of biding there.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No more; unless the next word that thou speak'st
Have some malignant power upon my life:
If so, I pray thee, breathe it in mine ear,
As ending anthem of my endless dolour.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Cease to lament for that thou canst not help,
And study help for that which thou lament'st.
Time is the nurse and breeder of all good.
Here if thou stay, thou canst not see thy love;
Besides, thy staying will abridge thy life.
Hope is a lover's staff; walk hence with that
And manage it against despairing thoughts.
Thy letters may be here, though thou art hence;
Which, being writ to me, shall be deliver'd
Even in the milk-white bosom of thy love.
The time now serves not to expostulate:
Come, I'll convey thee through the city-gate;
And, ere I part with thee, confer at large
Of all that may concern thy love-afairs.
As thou lovest Silvia, though not for thyself,
Regard thy danger, and along with me!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I pray thee, Launce, an if thou seest my boy
Bid him make haste and meet me at the Northgate.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Go, sirrah, find him out. Come, Valentine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O my dear Silvia! Hapless Valentine! [Exeunt Val. and Pro.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
I am but a fool, look you; and
yet I have
the wit to think my master is a kind
of a knave: but
that's all one, if he be but one
knave. He lives not now
that knows me to be
in love; yet I am in love; but a
team of horse
shall not pluck that from me; nor who
'tis I
love; and yet 'tis a woman; but what woman,
I
will not tell myself; and yet 'tis a milkmaid;
yet 'tis
not a maid, for she hath had gossips;
yet 'tis a maid,
for she is her master's maid,
and serves for wages. She
hath more qualities
than a water-spaniel; which is
much in a bare
Christian. [Pulling out a paper.] Here is
the cate-log of her
condition. 'Imprimis: She
can fetch and carry.' Why,
a horse can do no
no more: nay, a horse cannot fetch, but
only
carry; therefore is she better than a jade.
'Item:
She can milk;' look you, a sweet virtue
in a maid with
clean hands. Enter SPEED.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
How now, Signior Launce! what
news with
your mastership?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
With my master's ship? why, it
is at sea.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Well, your old vice still; mistake
the word. What
news, then, in your paper?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
The blackest news that ever thou
heardest.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Why, man, how black?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Why, as black as ink.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Let me read them.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Fie on thee, jolt-head! thou canst
not read.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Thou liest; I can.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
I will try thee. Tell me this: who
begot thee?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Marry, the son of my grandfather.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
O illiterate loiterer! it was the son
of thy
grandmother: this proves that thou
canst not read.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Come, fool, come; try me in thy
paper.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
There; and Saint Nicholas be thy
speed!

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: 'Imprimis: She can milk.'

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Ay, that she can.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: 'Item: She brews good ale.'

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
And thereof comes the proverb:
'Blessing of
your heart, you brew good ale.'

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: 'Item: She can sew.'

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
That's as much as to say, Can she
so?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: 'Item: She can knit.'

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
What need a man care for a stock
with a wench,
when she can knit him a stock?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: 'Item: She can wash and scour.'

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
A special virtue; for then she
need not be
washed and scoured.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: 'Item: She can spin.'

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Then may I set the world on
wheels, when she
can spin for her living.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
'Item: She hath many nameless
virtues.'

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
That's as much as to say, bastard
virtues; that,
indeed, know not their fathers
and therefore have no
names.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: 'Here follow her vices.'

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Close at the heels of her virtues.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
'Item: She is not to be kissed fasting,
in respect of her
breath.'

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Well, that fault may be mended
with a breakfast.
Read on.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: 'Item: She hath a sweet mouth.'

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
That makes amends for her sour
breath.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: 'Item: She doth talk in her sleep.'

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
It's no matter for that, so she
sleep not in her
talk.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: 'Item: She is slow in words.'

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
O villain, that set this down
among her vices!
To be slow in words is a
woman's only virtue:
I pray thee, out with't, and place it
for her chief virtue.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: 'Item: She is proud.'

sp.speaker: Launce.
Speed.
sp.p: 'Item: She hath no teeth.'

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
I care not for that neither, because
I love crusts.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: 'Item: She is curst.'

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Well, the best is, she hath no teeth
to bite.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
'Item: She will often praise her
liquor.'

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
If her liquor be good, she shall:
if she will not,
I will; for good things should
be praised.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: 'Item: She is too liberal.'

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Of her tongue she cannot, for
that's writ down
she is slow of; of her purse
she shall not, for that I'll
keep shut: now, of
another thing she may, and that
cannot I help.
Well, proceed.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
'Item: She hath more hair than
wit, and more
faults than hairs, and more
wealth than faults.'

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Stop there; I'll have her: she was
mine, and not
mine, twice or thrice in that last
article. Rehearse that
once more.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
'Item: She hath more hair than
wit,'--

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
More hair than wit? It may be;
I'll prove it. The
cover of the salt hides the
salt, and therefore it is more
than the salt; the
hair that covers the wit is more
than the wit,
for the greater hides the less. What's
next?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: 'And more faults than hairs.'--

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
That's monstrous: O, that that
were out!

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: 'And more wealth than faults.'

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Why, that word makes the faults
gracious.
Well, I'll have her: and if it be a
match, as nothing is
impossible,--

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Why, then will I tell thee--that
thy master stays
for thee at the North-gate.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: For me?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
For thee! ay, who art thou? he hath stayed for a better
man than thee.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: And must I go to him?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Thou must run to him, for thou
hast stayed so long
that going will scarce serve
the turn.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Why didst not tell me sooner? pox
of your
love-letters! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Now will he be swinged for reading
my letter;
an unmannerly slave, that will
thrust himself into secrets!
I'll after, to rejoice
in the boy's correction. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Sir Thurio, fear not but that she will love you,
Now Valentine is banish'd from her sight.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: Since his exile she hath despised me most,
Forsworn my company and rail'd at me,
That I am desperate of obtaining her.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: This weak impress of love is as a figure
Trenched in ice, which with an hour's heat
Dissolves to water and doth lose his form.
A little time will melt her frozen thoughts
And worthless Valentine shall be forgot. Enter PROTEUS.
How now, Sir Proteus! Is your countryman
According to our proclamation gone?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Gone, my good lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: My daughter takes his going grievously.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: A little time, my lord, we will kill that grief.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: So I believe; but Thurio thinks not so.
Proteus, the good conceit I hold of thee--
For thou hast shown some sign of good desert--
Makes me the better to confer with thee.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Longer than I prove loyal to your grace
Let me not live to look upon your grace.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Thou know'st how willingly I would effect
The match between Sir Thurio and my daughter.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I do, my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: And also, I think, thou art not ignorant
How she opposes her against my will.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: She did, my lord, when Valentine was here.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Ay, and perversely she persevers so.
What might we do to make the girl forget
The love of Valentine and love Sir Thurio?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: The best way is to slander Valentine
With falsehood, cowardice and poor descent,
Three things that women highly hold in hate.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Ay, but she'll think that it is spoke in hate.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Ay, if his enemy deliver it:
Therefore it must with circumstance be spoken
By one whom she esteemeth as his friend.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Then you must undertake to slander him.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: And that, my lord, I shall be loath to do:
'Tis an ill office for a gentleman,
Especially against his very friend.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Where your good word cannot advantage him,
Your slander cannot endamage him;
Therefore the office is indifferent,
Being entreated to it by your friend.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: You have prevail'd, my lord: if I can do it
By aught that I can speak in his dispraise,
She shall not long continue love to him.
But say this weed her love from Valentine,
It follows not that she will love Sir Thurio.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: Therefore, as you unwind her love from him,
Lest it should ravel and be good to none,
You must provide to bottom it on me;
Which must be done by praising me as much
As you in worth dispraise Sir Valentine.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: And, Proteus, we dare trust you in this kind,
Because we know, on Valentine's report,
You are already Love's firm votary
And cannot soon revolt and change your mind.
Upon this warrant shall you have access
Where you with Silvia may confer at large;
For she is lumpish, heavy, melancholy,
And, for your friend's sake, will be glad of you;
Where you may temper her by your persuasion
To hate young Valentine and love my friend.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: As much as I can do, I will effect:
But, you, Sir Thurio, are not sharp enough;
You must lay lime to tangle her desires
By wailful sonnets, whose composed rhymes
Should be full-fraught with serviceable vows,

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Ay,
Much is the force of heaven-bred poesy.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Say that upon the altar of her beauty
You sacrifice your tears, your sighs, your heart:
Write till your ink be dry, and with your tears
Moist it again, and frame some feeling line
That may discover such integrity:
For Orpheus' lute was strung with poets' sinews,
Whose golden touch could soften steel and stones,
Make tigers tame and huge leviathans
Forsake unsounded deeps to dance on sands.
After your dire-lamenting elegies,
Visit by night your lady's chamber-window
With some sweet concert; to their instruments
Tune a deploring dump: the night's dead silence
Will well become such sweet-complaining grievance.
This, or else nothing, will inherit her.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: This discipline shows thou hast been in love.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.l: And thy advice this night I'll put in practice.
Therefore, sweet Proteus, my direction-giver,
Let us into the city presently
To sort some gentlemen well skill'd in music.
I have a sonnet that will serve the turn
To give the onset to thy good advice.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: About it, gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: We'll wait upon your grace till after supper,
And afterward determine our proceedings.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Even now about it! I will pardon you. [Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE I
div2.stage: The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.

sp.speaker: First Out.
sp.l: Fellows, stand fast; I see a passenger.

sp.speaker: Sec. Out.
sp.l: If there be ten, shrink not, but down with 'em. Enter VALENTINE and SPEED.

sp.speaker: Third Out.
sp.l: Stand, sir, and throw us that you have about ye:
If not, we'll make you sit and rifle you.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Sir, we are undone; these are the villains
That all the travellers do fear so much.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My friends,--

sp.speaker: First Out.
sp.l: That's not so, sir: we are your enemies.

sp.speaker: Sec. Out.
sp.l: Peace! we'll hear him.

sp.speaker: Third Out.
sp.l: Ay, by my beard, will we, for he's a proper man.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Then know that I have little wealth to lose:
A man I am cross'd with adversity;
My riches are these poor habiliments,
Of which if you should here disfurnish me,
You take the sum and substance that I have.

sp.speaker: Sec. Out.
sp.p: Whither travel you?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: To Verona.

sp.speaker: First Out.
sp.p: Whence came you?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: From Milan.

sp.speaker: Third Out.
sp.l: Have you long sojourned there?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Some sixteen months, and longer might have stay'd,
If crooked fortune had not thwarted me.

sp.speaker: First Out.
sp.l: What, were you banish'd thence?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I was.

sp.speaker: Sec. Out.
sp.p: For what offence?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: For that which now torments me to rehearse:
I kill'd a man, whose death I much repent;
But yet I slew him manfully in fight,
Without false vantage or base treachery.

sp.speaker: First Out.
sp.l: Why, ne'er repent it, if it were done so.
But were you banish'd for so small a fault?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I was, and held me glad of such a doom.

sp.speaker: Sec. Out.
sp.l: Have you the tongues?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My youthful travel therein made me happy,
Or else I often had been miserable.

sp.speaker: Third Out.
sp.l: By the bare scalp of Robin Hood's fat friar.
This fellow were a king for our wild faction!

sp.speaker: First Out.
sp.p: We'll have him. Sirs, a word.

sp.speaker: Speed.
Val.
sp.p: Peace, villain!

sp.speaker: Sec. Out.
sp.l: Tell us this: have you any thing to take to?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nothing but my fortune.

sp.speaker: Third Out.
sp.l: Know, then, that some of us are gentlemen,
Such as the fury of ungovern'd youth
Thrust from the company of awful men:
Myself was from Verona banished
For practising to steal away a lady,
An heir, and near allied unto the duke.

sp.speaker: Sec. Out.
sp.l: And I from Mantua, for a gentleman,
Who, in my mood, I stabb'd unto the heart.

sp.speaker: First Out.
sp.l: And I for such like petty crimes as these.
But to the purpose--for we cite our faults,
That they may hold excused our lawless lives;
And partly, seeing you are beautified
With goodly shape and by your own report
A linguist and a man of such perfection
As we do in our quality much want--

sp.speaker: Sec. Out.
sp.l: Indeed, because you are a banish'd man,
Therefore, above the rest, we parley to you:
Are you content to be our general?
To make a virtue of necessity
And live, as we do, in this wilderness?

sp.speaker: Third Out.
sp.l: What say'st thou? wilt thou be of our consort?
Say ay, and be captain of us all:
We'll do thee homage and be ruled by thee,
Love thee as our commander and our king.

sp.speaker: First Out.
sp.l: But if thou scorn our courtesy, thou diest.

sp.speaker: Sec. Out.
sp.l: Thou shalt not live to brag what we have offer'd.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I take your offer and will live with you,
Provided that you do no outrages
On silly women or poor passengers.

sp.speaker: Third Out.
sp.l: No, we detest such vile base practices.
Come, go with us, we'll bring thee to our crews,
And show thee all the treasure we have got;
Which, with ourselves, all rest at thy dispose. [Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE II
div2.stage: Milan. Outside the DUKE'S palace, under SILVIA'S chamber.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Already have I been false to Valentine
And now I must be as unjust to Thurio.
Under the colour of commending him,
I have access my own love to prefer:
But Silvia is too fair, too true, too holy,
To be corrupted with my worthless gifts.
When I protest true loyalty to her,
She twits me with my falsehood to my friend;
When to her beauty I commend my vows,
She bids me think how I have been forsworn
In breaking faith with Julia whom I loved:
And notwithstanding all her sudden quips,
The least whereof would quell a lover's hope,
Yet, spaniel-like, the more she spurns my love,
The more it grows and fawneth on her still.
But here comes Thurio: now must we to her window,
And give some evening music to her ear. Enter THURIO and Musicians.
